current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To protect and enhance opportunities for recreational
		  hunting, fishing, and shooting, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail:
introduced
			 the following bill; which was read twice and ordered placed on the
			 calendar

action-desc.#text: Read twice and ordered placed on the calendar

text.#text:
This Act may be cited
			 as the
The table of contents of this Act is as follows:

toc-entry.#text:
Sec. 1. Short title; table of
				contents.

Sec. 101. Recreational fishing, hunting, and recreational
				shooting on Federal public land.
Sec. 102. Transporting bows through National Parks.

Sec. 103. Firearms at water resources development
				projects.

Sec. 104. Permits for importation of polar bear trophies taken
				in sport hunts in Canada.

Sec. 105. Target practice and marksmanship training on Federal
				land.

Sec. 301. Federal Land Transaction Facilitation
				Act.
Sec. 302. North American Wetlands Conservation Act.

Sec. 401. Modification of definition of sport fishing equipment
				under the Toxic Substances Control Act.

Sec. 402. Annual permit and fee for film crews of 5 persons or
				fewer.

header.#text:
Recreational
			 fishing, hunting, and recreational shooting

text.#text:
Subject to valid existing rights, and in cooperation with
			 the respective State and fish and wildlife agency, a Federal public land
			 management official shall exercise the authority of the official under existing
			 law (including provisions regarding land use planning) to facilitate use of and
			 access to Federal public land for recreational fishing, hunting, and
			 recreational shooting except as limited by—

any other Federal
			 law that precludes recreational fishing, hunting, or recreational shooting on
			 specific Federal public land or water or units of Federal public land;
			 and

discretionary
			 limitations on recreational fishing, hunting, and recreational shooting
			 determined to be necessary and reasonable as supported by the best scientific
			 evidence and advanced through a transparent public process.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the head of each Federal public land management agency
			 shall exercise the land management discretion of the head—

text.#text:
Consistent
			 with

to the extent
			 authorized under applicable State law; and

in accordance
			 with applicable Federal law.

Federal public land planning documents
			 (including land resources management plans, resource management plans, travel
			 management plans, and energy development plans) shall include a specific
			 evaluation of the effects of the plans on opportunities to engage in
			 recreational fishing, hunting, or recreational shooting.

header.#text:
Evaluation of
			 effects on opportunities to engage in recreational fishing, hunting, or
			 recreational shooting

text.#text:
planning for or
			 determining which units of Federal public land are open for recreational
			 fishing, hunting, or recreational shooting; or

setting the
			 levels of use for recreational fishing, hunting, or recreational shooting on
			 Federal public land.

Federal public land management officials shall not be
			 required to consider the existence or availability of recreational fishing,
			 hunting, or recreational shooting opportunities on private or public land that
			 is located adjacent to, or in the vicinity of, Federal public land for purposes
			 of—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
if the combination of
			 those opportunities would enhance the recreational fishing, hunting, or
			 shooting opportunities available to the public.

text.#text:
Federal public land management officials may
			 consider the opportunities described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
of an agency shall,
			 after appropriate coordination with State fish and wildlife agencies, allow the
			 participation of skilled volunteers in the culling and other management of
			 wildlife populations on Federal public land unless the head of the agency
			 demonstrates, based on the best scientific data available or applicable Federal
			 law, why skilled volunteers should not be used to control overpopulation of
			 wildlife on the land that is the subject of the planning document.

text.#text:
If hunting is prohibited by law, all Federal public
			 land planning documents described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
(including a component of the National
			 Wilderness Preservation System, land designated as a wilderness study area or
			 administratively classified as wilderness eligible or suitable, and primitive
			 or semiprimitive areas, but excluding land on the outer Continental Shelf)
			 shall be open to recreational fishing, hunting, and recreational shooting
			 unless the managing Federal public land agency acts to close the land to the
			 activity.

text.#text:
Nothing in this section requires a Federal agency to
			 give preference to recreational fishing, hunting, or recreational shooting over
			 other uses of Federal public land or over land or water management priorities
			 established by other Federal law.

In carrying out this section, the heads of Federal
			 public land agencies shall consult with the appropriate advisory councils

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:

			 to facilitation of hunting heritage and wildlife conservation)

text.#text:
Nothing in this section interferes with, diminishes, or
			 conflicts with the authority, jurisdiction, or responsibility of any State to
			 manage, control, or regulate fish and wildlife under State law (including
			 regulations) on land or water within the State, including on Federal public
			 land.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, nothing in this
			 subsection authorizes the head of a Federal public land agency head to require
			 a license, fee, or permit to fish, hunt, or trap on land or water in a State,
			 including on Federal public land in the State.

bowhunting

			 financial and human resources to wildlife conservation and youth education
			 programs throughout the United States; and

bowhunting
			 contributes $38,000,000,000 each year to the economy of the United
			 States.

Target
			 practice and marksmanship training on Federal land

text.#text:
the use of firearms and archery equipment
			 for target practice and marksmanship training activities on Federal land is
			 allowed, except to the extent specific portions of that land have been closed
			 to those activities;

providing opportunities for target practice
			 and marksmanship training at public target ranges on Federal and non-Federal
			 land can help—

to promote enjoyment of shooting,
			 recreational, and hunting activities; and

to ensure safe and convenient locations for
			 those activities;

Federal law in effect on the date of
			 enactment of this Act, including the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, provides Federal support for construction and
			 expansion of public target ranges by making available to States amounts that
			 may be used for construction, operation, and maintenance of public target
			 ranges; and

text.#text:
it is in the public interest to provide
			 increased Federal support to facilitate the construction or expansion of public
			 target ranges.

The purpose of this section is to
			 facilitate the construction and expansion of public target ranges, including
			 ranges on Federal land managed by the
